skill.name: networkx
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python. Use when working with network/graph data structures, analyzing relationships between entities, computing graph algorithms (shortest paths, centrality, clustering), detecting communities, generating synthetic networks, or visualizing network topologies. Applicable to social networks, biological networks, transportation systems, citation networks, and any domain involving pairwise relationships.
skill.summary: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing markdown files with Python code examples. All 479 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misinterpreting markdown syntax (backticks), graph algorithm names (e.g., betweenness, PageRank, dfs, bfs), and legitimate file I/O function names. No executable code, no credential access, no network calls for data exfiltration.

content.value_statement: NetworkX provides Python tools for building, analyzing, and visualizing graph structures. Use it to model relationships in social networks, biological systems, or any connected data. It handles everything from basic graph creation to advanced algorithms like community detection and centrality analysis.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate graph structures (Graph, DiGraph, MultiGraph, MultiDiGraph)
Compute graph algorithms including shortest paths, centrality measures, and PageRank
Generate synthetic networks using models like BarabÃ¡si-Albert and Watts-Strogatz
Detect communities and analyze clustering in networks
Read and write graphs in multiple formats (GraphML, GML, edge lists, JSON)
Visualize networks with customizable layouts using matplotlib
limitations: Not designed for real-time streaming graph data processing
Large graphs may require memory optimization techniques
Visualization limited to 2D plots; 3D requires integration with other libraries
Algorithms assume the graph fits in memory; distributed processing requires external tools

use_cases.title: Social network analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze relationship patterns, identify influential nodes, and detect communities in social media data.

use_cases.title: Biological network modeling
use_cases.description: Model protein interactions, gene regulatory networks, and phylogenetic relationships.

use_cases.title: Route optimization
use_cases.description: Find shortest paths, optimize delivery routes, and analyze network connectivity.

prompt_templates.title: Basic graph creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a graph in NetworkX, add nodes and edges with attributes, and check the basic structure.

prompt_templates.title: Path finding
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I find the shortest path between two nodes in NetworkX? Include weighted edges and multiple path options.

prompt_templates.title: Centrality analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate betweenness, degree, and PageRank centrality for a graph. Explain when to use each measure.

prompt_templates.title: Network generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a scale-free network using the BarabÃ¡si-Albert model and a small-world network using Watts-Strogatz. Compare their properties.

output_examples.input: Create a graph from edge list data and find the most central nodes
output: Created graph with 50 nodes and 234 edges
Top 5 nodes by degree centrality: Node 12 (0.82), Node 7 (0.71), Node 23 (0.68), Node 45 (0.65), Node 3 (0.61)
Betweenness centrality identifies Node 12 as critical bridge (0.45), Node 7 as secondary bridge (0.32)
Graph is connected with diameter 4 and average clustering coefficient 0.38

best_practices: Set random seeds (seed=42) for reproducible graph generation and layouts
Use sparse matrices for large graphs to reduce memory consumption
Save graphs in GraphML format to preserve all node and edge attributes
Use approximate algorithms with k parameter for large centrality calculations
anti_patterns: Loading entire large graphs when only subgraph analysis is needed
Using floating-point weights in algorithms requiring exact comparisons
Forgetting to set graph type (DiGraph vs Graph) before adding directed edges
Not checking graph connectivity before running algorithms that require connected graphs

faq.question: What graph types does NetworkX support?
faq.answer: NetworkX supports Graph (undirected), DiGraph (directed), MultiGraph (undirected with multiple edges), and MultiDiGraph (directed with multiple edges).

faq.question: How do I read a graph from a CSV file?
faq.answer: Use nx.from_pandas_edgelist(df, 'source', 'target', edge_attr=['weight']) to create a graph from a pandas DataFrame containing edge data.

faq.question: What is the difference between centrality measures?
faq.answer: Degree centrality measures direct connections, betweenness measures shortest path influence, closeness measures average distance to all nodes, and PageRank measures recursive importance.

faq.question: How do I visualize a large network?
faq.answer: Use spring_layout with seed for reproducibility, consider sampling nodes for display, and adjust node size and edge width based on computed metrics.

faq.question: Can NetworkX handle weighted graphs?
faq.answer: Yes. Pass weight='attr_name' to algorithms to use edge weights. Many algorithms support weights including shortest_path, betweenness_centrality, and minimum_spanning_tree.

faq.question: How do I detect communities in a network?
faq.answer: Use community.greedy_modularity_communities(G) for modularity-based detection or community.label_propagation_communities(G) for faster label propagation.
